head.title: The Road to Kabul, Mired in Mines

hedline.hl1: The Road to Kabul, Mired in Mines

abstract.p: Letter from Martin Barber, United Nations Mine Action Service, emphasizes urgent need to rebuild road from Kabul to Kandahar, necessitating clearance of land mines; says land mine clearance should be top priority in rebuilding any countries emerging from conflict (Aug 31 article and Sept 3 editorial)

block.p: A Sept. 3 editorial and an Aug. 31 news article about Afghanistan highlight the urgent need to rebuild the road connecting Kabul, the capital, with Kandahar. Among the obstacles to the reconstruction of this lifeline for commerce, resettlement and national unity are the many land mines laid on or along it.

A Sept. 3 editorial and an Aug. 31 news article about Afghanistan highlight the urgent need to rebuild the road connecting Kabul, the capital, with Kandahar. Among the obstacles to the reconstruction of this lifeline for commerce, resettlement and national unity are the many land mines laid on or along it.

All mines must be cleared before the road can be finished. In Afghanistan, as in other countries, mine clearance is a prerequisite for reconstruction and development. The Japanese and the United States governments, the European Commission and the World Bank are helping finance demining operations to make major routes in Afghanistan safe for construction crews and the Afghans whose livelihoods and futures depend on them.

Donor governments, aid agencies and development organizations working elsewhere would do well to follow the lead of our partners in Afghanistan and make ''mine action'' an integral part of every effort to rebuild countries emerging from conflict.
MARTIN BARBER Director United Nations Mine Action Service New York, Sept. 3, 2003
